Texts.EssentialQuestion: What defines justice?
Texts.Title: Diana and Actaeon
Texts.Author: Thomas Bulfinch (adapted)

Texts.EssentialQuestion: How can smart thinking help solve a difficult problem?
Texts.Title: Rumple Skinny Stilts: A One-Act Play
Texts.Author: Elizabeth Massie
Texts.Description: A story from the book Wagging the Tales, where traditional fairy tales and modern fairy tales are told using contemporary dialogue from a present-day perspective. Each tale includes issues the characters face and the lessons that can be learned.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: How does luck, or fate, affect the story?
Texts.Title: What If the Goddess of Love Was Your Mother-in-Law?
Texts.Author: Rosalie F. Baker
Texts.Description: What if the Goddess of Love Was Your Mother-in-Law? There are many tales of romance but one of the best centers on the son of Aphrodite: Eros.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: How do people find love?
Texts.Title: The Invisible Red String
Texts.Author: Quen Law
Texts.Description: Ju-Lin is a young Chinese girl living in poverty with her family. When her family must sell her to make ends meet, a traditional Chinese matchmaker buys her to serve as her apprentice.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: What determines a person's destiny?
Texts.Title: Two Destinies
Texts.Author: B. C. Bond
Texts.Description: A story of the young Siddhartha, who would become the Buddha, choosing between becoming a king or a sage.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: How do authors use foreshadowing to make a story interesting for readers?
Texts.Title: The Difficult Path
Texts.Author: Grace Lin
Texts.Publisher: FLYING LESSONS & OTHER STORIES: The Difficult Path. Text copyright © 2001 by Grace Lin. Reprinted by permission of Writers House LLC acting as agent for the author.
Texts.Description: A story about a young servant girl whose life is changed by being able to read.
Texts.Territories: US AS GU MP PR VI

Texts.EssentialQuestion: What skills or lessons make a person a good leader?
Texts.Title: The Adventures of Theseus
Texts.Author: James Baldwin

Texts.EssentialQuestion: What makes a person heroic?
Texts.Title: Perseus: The Quest of Medusa's Head
Texts.Author: James Baldwin

Texts.EssentialQuestion: How do different cultures explain creation?
Texts.Title: The Blackfeet Creation
Texts.Author: Blackfoot Sacred Story
Texts.Description: This Blackfoot story was recorded in Blackfeet Indian Stories by George Bird Grinnell.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: What does it mean to have lived a good life?
Texts.Title: The Last Night of the World
Texts.Author: Ray Bradbury
Texts.Publisher: Reprinted by permission of Don Congdon Associates, Inc. Copyright © 1952 by the Crowell Collier Publishing Company, renewed 1980 by Ray Bradbury
Texts.Description: A married couple awakens to the knowledge that the world is going to end that very evening. Nonetheless, they go through their normal routines, knowing and accepting the fact that there is no tomorrow.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: How can it feel to end a close relationship?
Texts.Title: The Story of an Hour
Texts.Author: Kate Chopin
Texts.Description: '"The Story of an Hour" is a short story written by Kate Chopin on April 19, 1894, and originally published in Vogue on December 6, 1894 as "The Dream of an Hour".

Texts.EssentialQuestion: What would you sacrifice for romantic love?
Texts.Title: The Little Mermaid
Texts.Author: Hans Christian Andersen
Texts.Description: "The Little Mermaid" (Danish: Den lille havfrue) is a fairy tale by the Danish author Hans Christian Andersen about a young mermaid willing to give up her life in the sea and her identity as a mermaid to gain a human soul and the love of a human prince. The tale was first published in 1837 and has been adapted to various media, including musical theatre and animated film.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: How do people make moral decisions?
Texts.Title: Young Goodman Brown
Texts.Author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
Texts.Description: Young Goodman Brown is a short story published in 1835 by American writer Nathaniel Hawthorne. The story takes place in 17th century Puritan New England, a common setting for Hawthorne's works, and addresses the Calvinist/Puritan belief that all of humanity exists in a state of depravity, except those who are born in a state of grace. Hawthorne frequently attempts to expose the hypocrisy of Puritan culture in his literature. In a symbolic fashion, the story follows Young Goodman Brown's journey into self-scrutiny, which results in his loss of virtue and faith.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: How is happiness influenced by one's surroundings?
Texts.Title: The Big Trip Up Yonder
Texts.Author: Kurt Vonnegut, Jr.
Texts.Description: In a world where people can prevent themselves from aging and dying, problems arise due to overpopulation.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: What makes an ending happy?
Texts.Title: A Little Journey
Texts.Author: Ray Bradbury
Texts.Description: Ray Bradbury's "A Little Journey" was published in the August 1951 edition of the magazine Galaxy Science Fiction.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: What are the consequences of vanity?
Texts.Title: Dædalus and Icarus
Texts.Author: E. M. Berens
Texts.Description: Dædalus, a descendant of Erechtheus, was an Athenian architect, sculptor, and mechanician. He was the firstto introduce the art of sculpture in its higher development, for before his time statues were merely rude representations, having the limbs altogether undefined.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: How do we determine whether people "deserve" their fate?
Texts.Title: Narcissus and Echo
Texts.Author: Ovid (adapted)

Texts.EssentialQuestion: What are the dangers of trying to change our fate?
Texts.Title: The Monkey's Paw
Texts.Author: W.W. Jacobs
Texts.Description: "The Monkey's Paw" is a supernatural short story by author W. W. Jacobs first published in England in 1902. In the story, three wishes are granted to the owner of the monkey's paw, but the wishes come with an enormous price for interfering with fate.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: How does a lack of freedom affect our psyche?
Texts.Title: The Yellow Wallpaper
Texts.Author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
Texts.Description: "The Yellow Wallpaper" is a 6,000-word short story by the American writer Charlotte Perkins Gilman, first published in January 1892. It is regarded as an important early work of American feminist literature, illustrating attitudes in the 19th century toward women's physical and mental health. The instruction focuses on characterization, setting, conflict, imagery, simile, personification, connotation, and close analysis of a text.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: Should people be blamed for accidental outcomes caused by their actions?
Texts.Title: A Sound of Thunder
Texts.Author: Ray Bradbury
Texts.Publisher: Reprinted by permission of Don Congdon Associates, Inc. Copyright © 1952 by the Crowell Collier Publishing Company, renewed 1980 by Ray Bradbury
Texts.Description: "A Sound of Thunder" is a science fiction short story by Ray Bradbury, first published in Collier's magazine in the June 28, 1952 issue. The story begins in the future, in which the time machine has been invented but is still very temperamental. A hunter named Eckels pays to go traveling back into the past on a guided safari to kill a Tyrannosaurus rex.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: Is fate inescapable?
Texts.Title: Perseus
Texts.Author: E. M. Berens
Texts.Description: Perseus is best known as the hero who slayed Medusa. This myth explains how he became a hero and what he did with Medusa's head.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: Can you avoid fate?
Texts.Title: August Heat
Texts.Author: W. F. Harvey
Texts.Description: I have had what I believe to be the most remarkable day in my life, and while the events are still fresh in my mind, I wish to put them down on paper as clearly as possible.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: What kind of equality could be harmful for both individuals and society?
Texts.Title: Harrison Bergeron
Texts.Author: Kurt Vonnegut
Texts.Publisher: Harrison Bergeron, copyright © 1961 by Kurt Vonnegut, copyright renewed © 1989 by Kurt Vonnegut; from WELCOME TO THE MONKEY HOUSE by Kurt Vonnegut. Used by permission of Dell Publishing, an imprint of Random House, a division of Penguin Random House LLC. All rights reserved.
Texts.Description:
"Harrison Bergeron" is a satirical and dystopian science-fiction short story written by Kurt Vonnegut and first published in October 1961. Originally published in The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction, the story was republished in the author's Welcome to the Monkey House collection in 1968.

The story was written as a satire to offer a critique on people's claims that we should all be equal. It has been embraced by those critical of egalitarianism as an allegory of caution against socially enforced equality, more specifically the dangers of enforcing equality by virtue of leveling.
Texts.Territories: US AS GU MP PR VI

Texts.EssentialQuestion: What truth or advice is the author trying to convey?
Texts.Title: The Devil and Tom Walker
Texts.Author: Washington Irving
Texts.Description: "The Devil and Tom Walker" is a short story by Washington Irving that first appeared in his 1824 collection of stories titled Tales of a Traveller, as part of the "Money-Diggers" section.

Texts.EssentialQuestion: What does it mean to grow old?
Texts.Title: Dr. Heidegger's Experiment
Texts.Author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
Texts.Description: Dr. Heidegger's Experiment is a short story by American author Nathaniel Hawthorne, about a doctor who claims to have been sent water from the Fountain of Youth.
